issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) declares ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough as a boolean, and instructs a constructor taking attributes in that order (excellencyLevel, excellentEnough, rides) with corresponding getters. The solution, however, declares excellentEnough as a String, uses a constructor parameter of type String, and provides a getter returning String. This type mismatch affects the attribute, the constructor signature and the getter return type, and will confuse students who implement the attribute as boolean per the specification and task description (and may cause tests to fail).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough a boolean everywhere (template and solution). Update the ExcellenceLand constructor parameter to boolean (keeping the parameter order: double excellencyLevel, boolean excellentEnough, List<Ride> rides) and change the getter to return boolean. Update any tests or usages accordingly so the implementation matches the UML and the exercise instructions.

issues.description: The UML/problem statement specifies ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough as a boolean attribute, but the solution implementation declares excellentEnough as a String (and the constructor and getter use String). This is a semantic mismatch with the problem's attribute type: students are instructed to implement the attribute as boolean (per UML) but the reference solution uses a different type, which creates confusion about the expected type and constructor signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the UML/problem statement by changing the excellentEnough attribute (and its constructor parameter and getter) to type boolean. For example: declare 'private boolean excellentEnough;', update the constructor signature to accept a boolean for excellentEnough, and return boolean from getExcellentEnough().
